FIFA World Cup.passage:
[1]
"The 2010 FIFA World Cup was the tenth FIFA World Cup. The tournament was held from 11 June to 27 July 2010 in South Africa, with matches played across 12 cities in 11 countries. The 32 nations who participated were drawn into eight groups of four, and the top two teams in each group advanced to the knockout stages. A total of 64 games were played in South Africa, with only 23 matches in the knockout stage. The match schedule was completed before the end of the World Cup, making this tournament the fastest of the previous 9 World Cup's and one of the shortest FIFA World Cup's overall. The tournament is the first since 1998 in which a single goal was scored by an African team. The first goal in an African World Cup was scored in 2010."

Wimbledon Championships.passage:
1980
The tennis championships at the All England Club in Wimbledon, Great Britain, held from 27 June - 10 July 1980. It was the first major tournament of the year, and the seventh consecutive tournament where a non-British won the Gentlemen's singles trophy. American Jimmy Connors was the winner, winning the final in straight sets 6-1, 6-2, 6-2, over the Czechoslovakian player Jan McNichols. The tournament also saw the debut of 1970s tennis stars Bjorn Borg and Roger Federer.

French Open.passage:
2006: Men's singles
The 2006 French Open was the most successful edition of the event in terms of number of different players from different countries to make a last-64 appearance, but it still featured some surprising results and the "out of nowhere" victories. Many tennis experts believed that Roger Federer had little chance of winning, as he had not defeated a top-five player in a clay-court event all year. He was grouped with 15th-ranked David Nalbandian, the 2003 champion Fabrice Santoro, and 18th-ranked Gastón Gaudio. The Spaniard, who had lost in the first round the previous year, went out in the quarterfinals, after being sent home by a leg injury. In the semifinals, both Federer and Gaudio met the top seed, and both had to withdraw due to injuries. Thus, Federer lost in his second semifinal in a row. On the women's side, Venus Williams was the only top-10 player to reach the quarterfinals. She had no problems with the three seeded players on her side, but lost to unseeded French wildcard Nathalie Dechy in the quarters.

qae_pairs.question: Who won the 2006 French Open mens singles?
qae_pairs.explanation: 2006 French Open mens singles champion Roger Federer.

qae_pairs.question: Who is the only woman to reach the quarterfinals in 2006 French Open?
qae_pairs.explanation: 2006 French Open was the last French Open in which a non-French player was able to reach the quarterfinals. Nathalie Dechy, a French wildcard, defeated Venus Williams in the quarterfinals.

Ryder Cup.passage:
2010 at Valhalla, KY.
Ryder Cup: 2010 at Valhalla, KY
The 2010 Ryder Cup was a professional men's golf tournament held on September 12–14, 2010 at Valhalla Country Club in Louisville, Kentucky. It was the 36th Ryder Cup to take place at Valhalla. A total of 8,000 tickets were sold to spectators. The defending champion, the United States, won the event on a 8–4 scoreline, the second-highest margin of victory in the event's history. The event began on September 12, on Thursday, and concluded on September 14, with the matches on the Valhalla course in the morning of Friday, and the final matches on the Palmer course. The teams were comprised of the leading 12 players in the world rankings as of August 29, 2010, excluding the automatic qualifying players. The United States team won for the first time since 2008 with a 13 3/4–8 3/4 win over Europe. In 1998, they had been defeated by Europe, who were seeking to win a record fifth time in a row. This year's event was the second time the US were defeated by Europe, following on from 1998, with a 13 3/4–8 3/4 defeat.

the All England Club.passage: For nearly 200 years, the All England Club has been the home of tennis, and the headquarters of one of the world’s leading tennis clubs. The club was founded on the 14th August 1858, 200 years ago today, by a group of 28 amateur sportsmen. It is the first and only sports club to be founded in a modern country house (Eaton House), and the club has been at the center of British tennis for 200 years. The club is not associated with the British Royal Family, the current family head is King George VI. In 1937 the members voted for the first time to move the Wimbledon headquarters to the All England Club, but Wimbledon has been able to remain at its current location in SW19. Wimbledon.passage: "Each year, Wimbledon is held at The All England Club in London, England, over two weeks in late June and early July. The tournament is considered the'mother of all tennis tournaments' and is one of the biggest events in the world. Each year, it attracts a large number of the world's top tennis players, both male and female, from all over the world. The tournament has been held since 1877, when the All England Club was founded and has been held every year since. The tournament features singles and doubles competitions in both men's and women's categories, as well as mixed doubles. New England Patriots.passage:
History
From 1960-1970, the New England Patriots were a part-time minor league team in the 3rd tier of the American Football League. The 1970 version of the team was the New England Patriots in the National Football League (NFL) until they merged with the Montreal Expos in 1971. The NFL Patriots were renamed the New England Patriots in 1975 and have since won two Super Bowls.

the American Football Conference.passage:
The AFC (American Football Conference) is one of the four major professional football leagues in North America. It is the most popular of the three modern American sports leagues. It competes against the National Football League (NFL) and the National Hockey League (NHL). There are currently 32 teams in the AFC and each of them play 16 regular season games. The AFC has been around since 1970 when the NFL merged with the AFL. Grand Slams.passage:
In tennis, a grand slam is a tournament involving the world's four major championships. Grand Slam tournaments are among the most prestigious events in tennis and are typically seen as the ultimate tests of elite players. The four grand slams are:
- Wimbledon, held in late summer on grass courts
- The French Open, held in early summer on red clay courts in Paris
- The Australian Open, held in late January/early February on hard-court tennis in Melbourne
- The U.S. Open, held in late August on hard-court tennis in New York City. The big four grand slams (Wimbledon, Australian Open, U.S. Open, and French Open) take place on specific days or weeks of the year in a four-week period.
